bestBHT.bht: The demon, acknowledging Jesus as the Son of the Most High God, pleads, I adjure thee by God, that thou torment me not. The demon's cry reflects their fear and anticipation of the impending torment. This encounter reveals that even demons confess Jesus' divinity, underscoring the fact that one can have knowledge and confession of Christ, yet lack any personal relationship or genuine interest in Him.

Henry Alford: 7.] I adjure thee by God; “I beseech thee” Luke.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: What have I to do with thee, Jesus, Son of the most high God? I adjure thee by God, that thou torment me not."
Behold the tormentor anticipating, dreading, and entreating exemption from torment!"
In Christ they discern their destined Tormentor; the time, they know, is fixed, and they feel as if it were come already!
Marvin Vincent: Crying - he saith. The inarticulate cry (verse 5), and then the articulate speech.
What have I to do with thee? [τι εμοι και σοι; ] . Lit., what is there to me and thee? What have we in common?
I adjure thee by God. Stronger than Luke's I pray thee. The verb oJrkizw, I adjure, is condemned by the grammarians as inelegant.
Philip Schaff: Peculiar to Mark is the strong expression: I adjure thee by God.
The language of the demon, not of the man; not a mere blasphemy, but a plausible argument.
The highest acknowledgment comes from the most virulent demon.
Archibald T. Robertson: I adjure thee by God (ορκιζω σε τον θεον). The demoniac puts Jesus on oath (two accusatives) after the startled outcry just like the one in Mark 1:24, which see.
He calls Jesus here 'son of the Most High God' (υιε του θεου του υψιστου) as in Luke 8:28 (cf. Genesis 14:18).

Torment me not (μη με βασανισηις). Prohibition with μη and the ingressive aorist subjunctive. The word means to test metals and then to test one by torture (cf. our 'third degree'). Same word in all three Gospels.
John Gill: Devils believe there is one God, and tremble at him; and they confess that Jesus of Nazareth, who was born of the virgin, according to the human nature, is the Son of God, according to his divine nature.

Truly they choose not to have anything to do with God himself; they have cast off allegiance to him, and rebelled against him; and have left their estate, and departed from him; and still less do they care to have anything to do with his Son.

Men may know much of Christ notionally; may know, and confess him to be God, to be the Son of God, in the highest and true sense of the phrase; to be the Messiah, to have been incarnate, to have suffered, died, and risen again; to be ascended to heaven, from whence he will come again; and yet have no more to do with him, or have no more interest in him, than the devils themselves.

bhtAttempts.bht: The demon in the verse cries out to Jesus, acknowledging Him as the Son of the most high God and pleading with Him not to torment. By adjuring Jesus by God, the demon recognizes the authority and power of Jesus. The demon's fear and desperation is evident in their plea, as they anticipate and dread the torment they know is coming. This interaction reveals that even demons, who have rebelled against God and cast off their allegiance, confess Jesus as the Son of God. Their acknowledgment of Jesus' divinity goes beyond mere blasphemy and serves as a stark reminder that one can have knowledge and confession of Christ, yet still have no personal relationship or interest in Him.

The demon, recognizing Jesus as the Son of the Most High God, cries out, imploring Jesus not to torment. Through adjuring Jesus by God, the demon acknowledges Jesus' authority and power. Their desperate plea reflects their anticipation and dread of the impending torment. This encounter emphasizes that even demons confess Jesus' divinity, underscoring the fact that one can have knowledge and confession of Christ but lack any personal relationship or genuine interest in Him.

The demon, in acknowledging Jesus as the Son of the most high God, beseeches Him, saying, I adjure thee by God, that thou torment me not. The demon's cry reveals their awareness of Jesus as their destined Tormentor and their fear that the time of torment has come. Despite rebelling against God, even demons acknowledge Jesus' divinity. This serves as a reminder that one can possess knowledge and confession of Christ's identity without truly having a relationship or interest in Him.

The demon recognizes Jesus as the Son of the most high God, begging Him, I adjure thee by God, that thou torment me not. The demon's cry reveals their anticipation and dread of the torment to come. Even in rebellion, demons acknowledge Jesus' divinity. This understanding exposes how one can have knowledge and confession of Christ without truly engaging with Him.

The demon, acknowledging Jesus as the Son of the Most High God, pleads, I adjure thee by God, that thou torment me not. The demon's cry reflects their fear and anticipation of the impending torment. This encounter reveals that even demons confess Jesus' divinity, underscoring the fact that one can have knowledge and confession of Christ, yet lack any personal relationship or genuine interest in Him.
